question: Haven Hamilton is your father? Can you arrange an interview?
answer: Who the hell is playing piano? Get that hippie out of here... He's got a tin ear. I asked for Pig, dammit. I'm moving on 'cause I gotta get to the airport. When you get my backups straight, then we'll talk about cutting this tune here.

question: Excuse me, sir. I'm here putting together a film. I would like to ask some questions.
I'm from BBC television.
answer: Where the hell is that? Linnea.

question: 'Bye... nice talking to you.
Did you see who that was?
answer: Glad to see you. Ester'll be glad, too.

question: He is just wonderful.
Eater's been asking for you.
She's been in the hospital two weeks yesterday.
answer: You know anything about the stations here?

question: It's hard to say. Doctors thought she'd come home a week ago. All it was was appendix.
answer: All they got is advertisements. Just like L.A.

question: Did an exploratory and according to them, she needed an overhaul.
answer: Well, I could use one, especially if I'm pregnant.

question: What did you say?
answer: I said, maybe I'll change my name again.

question: I see... Well, those doctors are real miracle workers.
answer: But not unless Nashville really inspires me.

question: Maybe you can look after me a little.
Bud, would you be sure to get the oil changed?
answer: Ya... where do you want me to take it?

question: Where you always take it. There's nothing special about this time. Bud, you're going to have to show up at the hospital tar me I gotta get back to that session.
answer: Okay. Anything you want me to say?

question: Is that what you're going to sing?
answer: No -- That's exercises. My coach says you have to do exercise because the vocal chords are muscle and need to be stretched. Every time you stretch them, the middle part sets stronger. That's the place where I sing.

question: You think I got any kind of a voice?
Is that good?
You think I should take lessons?
answer: If you're serious. Being serious is real important.

question: You serious?
answer: Wade -- I've been working toward this audition for years.

question: Well, honey, I sure hope it comes your way then.
What do you think of him?
answer: Hal? Well, Hal and I have been friends for a long time.

question: You go to school together?
Oh --
answer: We're connected by a relative. One time, one of his aunts married one of my uncles. That was a long time ago, though. How'd you come to work for him?

question: Well, I really think he's got a chance.
Oh yea -- There has never been a better time for something new.
He is to a lot of people.
answer: He was a good Judge, but that was a long time ago.

question: You know, I'll bet you he makes it with a majority.
Southern California.
Spent time in Arizona. Why?
answer: Well, I admire your optimism, and I just wondered if it was regional. You ever see any movie stars?

question: I know a couple.
answer: No kidding -- Wait till I tell Linnea. Who?

question: Ah... Peter Finch.
Peter Finch -- he's English.
answer: I never heard of him. Name somebody else.

question: Ryan O'Neal.
answer: You really do? ~ God -- How come you know them?

question: Oh, you meet them at parties and stuff.
answer: I'll be damned. Boy, if you could get Ryan to say something about Hal Phillip Walker, wouldn't that be something?

question: Well -- maybe. Let's see what happens here.
Have your children been deaf since birth?
answer: Yes -- yes, they have. It was a real shock at first, especially since my daddy's a preacher, but Delbert and I have been blessed by their being here.

question: When did you start singing?
answer: When I was little, in church.

question: Isn't it unusual for you to be working with a black choir?
Well, can you tell me why?
How long have you been with them?
And before?
answer: Just my church and my boys. We all had to go to school and learn hand talking. I just thank the Lord they can see.

question: Do you ever do any writing?
Are you a close friend of Haven's?
answer: No, mostly his wife's. She's in Paris, France, right now. My husband Delbert is real friendly with him. Delbert's in law. Does work for him.

question: Do you like him?
answer: He's a member of our congregation.

question: You got the money?
Well, don't lose it. Last time I gave you twenty-five dollars, you lost it.
answer: Well, that just happened that time.

question: Well, it better not happen again. You lost twenty-five dollars once before that, too, near Christmas time -- I remember that real well now. December 9th, to be exact.
answer: You got a real good memory, Star.

question: I remember when I just saw you. Skinny Winnifred. Jesus, you were skinny.
answer: What do you have to buy?

question: Feed, mostly. Thought we'd get something for the kids.
answer: Okay by me - I'd sure like to see that Opryland.

question: What?
I hate that music.
Have you seen a woman about so high?
She had on high heels?
Anything you say. Doctor says you'll have to go on out now
answer: Excuse me, Barnett, how's she doing? I'm sorry. I feel as if I know you. I'm John Triplette... a friend of Del Reese... I was at the airport. I just wanted to introduce myself. I'm a great fan of hers. If there's anything you need, just give me a call. I'm at the Sheraton South.

question: She's going to rest now.
answer: Okay, I just wanted to see if I could help out at all.

question: I appreciate your concern, but she has to rest, so you can go on home.
What do you really want?
answer: Not a thing, Barnett, really. I need a little information. But, ah, it can wait.

question: You bet.
We just got a gold record.
answer: Do they have a show to give it to you?

question: No Hell, some secretary in New York just hands it to you. Only this one kept dropping it out of the box.
Dent it a little. Boy -- just she couldn1t even find it. She had a hamburger on her desk that looked three weeks old.
answer: How long have you been together?

question: Probably a little too long.
When do you need her? You want her to sing, too?
How much? You know... blonde. I can only give you fifty a week here and ten bucks for the benefit.
You go here Monday night and be there at eight sharp and look flashy you know what I mean? Are you sure you know what you're doing?
Well, there's a couple of girls in Printers Alley if you got any questions. I know I've seen that G- string stuff for sale someplace around.
answer: Don't you worry about Sueleen Gay.

question: That's for sure. At the airport - that's where it was. At the airport, there in one of those gift shops... Anyway, you better take a break.
answer: Thanks. You are just a wonderful person.

question: Hello.
Yes. Who's this?
Who is this?
I'm not sure. Where?
answer: Remember, about a month ago, your church choir cut a record?

question: Yes.
answer: Well, I met you that afternoon in the control room and we...

question: Oh, Tom, of course. What are you doing in Nashville?
answer: I'd really like to see you.

question: Or course. You should come over to the house. The boys would love to meet you.
answer: That's not quite what I had in mind.

question: Well...How have you been?
answer: Well, they removed my heart last week, but I'm doing fine except my nose fell off. Looks a little funny. Look, I find you attractive and I want to see you, so I'll call you when I get to my place.

question: Hey, there - You seen my Winifred?
You got a place to stay?
answer: No. Probably stay at a motel tonight.

question: You in music?
Yes, air.
Can I help you?
answer: Yes, sir. I need a room

question: I think we can do that. Come in. Green's the name.
answer: Kenneth Fraser. Glad to meet you...

question: My wire's been in the hospital so things might be a little dusty, but the sheets are clean and the bath's down the hall. You're in music, I guess, aren't you? 'Cause my niece sings most of the day. That won't bother you, will it? I didn't think it would. She's calling herself L.A. Joan this- week. Last week it was Dakota. Guess if you have to change your name a state's as good as anything.
My wife and I think so, but we're family. Your family's always good or bad depending on how you look at your family. What do you do, pick or sing?
answer: Oh... a little of both. Just thought I'd look around at Nashville for a while.

question: When you run out or money, 'cause you will here, you can go sing at Bishop's Pub. They let you pass the hat. All these kids do that. Most every place doesn't want to bother with you.
Well, don't be shy. I got the address here. Anytime you need it. Room's twenty-five dollar! a week and you can have breakfast with me if you like.
answer: Suits me. Listen, do you know anything about cars?

question: Sorry I'm late.
Where's Bill?
Where are you going?
He got killed at a turkey shoot.
Yes. I was in my Sophomore year at Harvard.
Business School so I can run Haven's business.
You go out in the woods and shoot targets -- Whoever shoots the most wins a live turkey
answer: How in the world did he get shot?

question: Some guy was drunk and hit him. Accident. Haven almost killed him.
Yes, sir. Like you to meet Opal.
answer: Need to have you check these out before he goes on that Walker benefit.

question: Sure thing. Put them here... I'll take them.
answer: Thanks... I'll... go say hello to your mom.

question: She's in Paris.
answer: Oh... Well... Have you heard from Barnett?

question: Not yet.
answer: Let me know when you do, all right?

question: You bet.
Do you know Barbara Jean?
answer: Sure do. Good friend of Haven's.

question: Haven's not going to talk to me.
Hi.
I'm Opal.

I'm gathering information about the characteristics of music people. I just finished a documentary on Gandi. The architect His buildings are drippy. You know, like sand and castles. Then I got this assignment. They want to start in two weeks.
Why?
Would you turn that off Barnett, please -
I don't want to listen to her sing
Then why are you listening to her -
answer: Well, I have to go thank her for filling in and it's nice to know the tune she sang.

question: You have to what?
answer: Go to the King Of the Road and thank her.

question: Well here, why don't you take her some of these flowers while you're at it. Maybe you'd like to work out something with her, too... Split us up... Her on the road and me in town or in the hospital -- Barnett!
answer: What the hell is wrong with you? Huh? Wait a minute. You're not going nutsey on me, are you? Huh...? You're not going to have one of those nervous breakdowns or anything, are you?

question: A... No... No, I'm just... I'm really fine... I just. don't want you to think I'm giving up or anything like that...
answer: I'll just take these on over to her. Show her your appreciation.

question: Sure... you go on and do that. Barnett?
answer: I'll tell her thank you, for you.

question: Barnett?
Bye, bye.
I just get so afraid sometimes. Then I get more afraid.
I'm really all right, Barnett. Don't you worry really... I just don't want you to leave me that's all. Oh, my God.
answer: Oh, honey, I didn't mean to scare you.

question: How did you come in here?
answer: Well, my wife, Ester's down the hall. I saw Barnett leaving and I was just talking to Ester about your being here. She loves you so much, I just had to come down and say hello. We've been following you since you were a girl. Well, I just scared you to death. I didn't mean to do that.

question: Well, I guess you caught me at a weak moment.
I said, I've been real tired.
answer: Eater says she doesn't see how you do it.

question: What's wrong with her.
answer: Oh just about everything, I guess. Those doctors started on an overhaul and don't want to quit. They keep taking things out. She's going to come home an egg shell. Tough, though.. She's tough.

question: What did you say your name was?
Glad to meet you.
Oh, no, listen, I don't want to take up too much of your time.
answer: Don't you worry. We're just having a quiet Sunday at home.

question: Well, I'm here putting together a show. It's a benefit really.
He's pretty well known down here.
answer: He's pretty well known all over.

question: I was wondering if you'd like to be in it. It's going to be televised and...
Bill, he's a crazy man.
answer: Well, he- expressed a particular wish to have you on.

question: What for?
Sure thing.
You're doing some recording here, aren't you?
Come on in. How's your stomach?
answer: Pretty good. Sure was surprised to hear from you. You talk to Bill?

question: Not yet. Listen, Norman, I want...
answer: They're looking all over for you. Do you have a copy of the album. You know Bill is really mad at you.

question: Oh?
Mary?
answer: You know, I've got my own act now. I'm going on tour.

question: Good...
answer: Listen, Tom, I have a tour to drive.

question: This your first time? You're from out of town?
We have a Bible study meeting tonight if you'd like to come.
No.
answer: Well, I just wondered 'cause being from out or town I wouldn't be able to make anything.

question: No, those are socials you're thinking of... Saturday's usually.
answer: Yes sir. I'm from Tallahassee. And I want you to know I round Jesus today, right here.

question: You weren't really going to drive off? My name's Opal. What's yours? You going to Nashville? Good. I came out here to meet some underground singer. They say she only writes in those trees over there. She never came. I'm trying to gather some information about the characteristics of music people for English television. I started in San Francisco. Some friends were making an anti-war film about 'Nam, you know, and I just love marine movies. It is really the consummate art form, all those parts of the puzzle to make the whole. All that energy being collective, you know what I mean? I've been all over the United States now except for Maine and Vermont. What did you say your name was?

Star - oh! that's a fantastic name. Almost as good as Opal. I changed my name in Taos. This man that was really into low budget movies said my eyes were opalistic. I'm going to make the consummate documentary as soon as I finish gathering information. You know it's so nice not to feel oppressed in a society that is male oriented.
What the hell?
Replacement party.
A guy named Walker. Amazing person. He's developed a huge following.
Well I've been following him around Just listening to him --He says he can really win -- I bet he can too -
Well, he's really amazing.
answer: I haven't gotten into politics yet. I'm still into music --except for you. You're into politics.

question: Ah, hello. My name is Kenneth Fraser... And I'm here from Terre Haute, Indiana. Ah, listen ... somebody stole my handles. Oh, well, thanks. Ah, oh, maybe you know where... Do you carry door handles? Nash. Sixty-three. Sure. Ill take it. I'll call back on the handles. Hey, when do they come on? Oh. He does and the PHONE RINGS. Hello? No, but I can give him a message. Oh my God! I thought you were at the hospital with your uncle! Listen, your Aunt Ester just died. I'm... sorry... Listen, I really Feel bad now about last night...We had no...
answer: I'm in a hurry, gonna see this great group record at Woodland.

question: I mean, Mr. Green was so nice to me. He took me in and...
answer: I don't really know what you're talking about.

question: I've got to get a hold of Mr. Green.
answer: Hope you don't mind me coming. I just love your music.

question: Howdy.
answer: Where the hell have you been?

question: You guys been having any fun?
To the bathroom.
How is she?
answer: A little slow, but she'll be fine.

question: Have you talked to Triplette?
He's lining up talent for Hal Phillip Walker.
He's going to run for president.
He has that sign with the tree.
Barbara Jean.
That's what he wants.
It's on National television, Barnett.
answer: I don't care. She's always been neutral in politics and that's not going to change.

question: Well, how about the shopping center?
Okay, then we'll see you there.
answer: Okay. Okay, come on, honey. How are you feeling?

question: You going today?
I'll tell Ester, she'll be thrilled I saw you again.
answer: You get her those Vitamin E right away.

question: I got them right here.
answer: Well, Bye, Bye now. We have to go.

question: Bye, Bye. Where have you got her hidden today?
Yes, ma'am. How are you today?
answer: Didn't you get?... How are you?

question: I'm fine. Can I go up?
answer: Let me see if I can get the doctor hold on one second.

question: You want me to wait?
answer: No. Mr. Green, I don't know how to tell you this -- your wire passed away -- I thought they'd called you at home.

question: What?
answer: Your wire Ester - she passed away. If you'll wait Just a minute I'll get everything from the business office.

question: Hello.
What?
answer: Who is this, right? I called you last night.

question: Oh.
Oh?
answer: End of Church Street. Next to a grocery store.

question: Doesn't it have a name?
answer: I can't remember. In out/out in, something like that. Around eight.

question: Hi, I'm Sueleen Gay.
answer: I'm John Triplette. Excuse me. I got all caught up in looking at you. You'll be fine.

question: Oh, why thank you.
You like it? Listen, where is the pianist? I need to go over this with him. You all didn't say what you wanted to hear. Someday I'm gonna be a star like Barbara Jean.
answer: Sueleen, you're prettier and probably sing better. Besides, she is unusually sick. And tonight you have the opportunity to work in front of some grateful gentlemen. Have you ever done this before? Well, it's not too hard. You'll sing whatever it is you want to sing. They'll applaud like crazy 'cause I can tell them that you're really something and then the piano and drum will give you a little fanfare and you can sing and take off your clothes or not sing. It really doesn't make much difference, really. But since you've never done this before, singing might help. Now this is to raise funds for someone who can help people who are less fortunate than yourself. The more you take off, you see, more money we can raise.

question: I see.
answer: I know that you are an artist and I am sure you are very religious. Well, this is for people who have a kind of religious belief in the way they live.

question: Don't you think they'd just love another song instead?
answer: Now, Sueleen, you know that's not what we talked about right here in this very room.

question: Here we are, Sueleen. Sueleen... Sueleen Gay.
Wait a minute! I want to look at you. C'mon.
C'mon! I Just wanna look... Good. I wanna look really good. You know what I mean? Do you? Huh? Oh.
answer: It'll be okay... It'll be okay... I know it'll be fine...

question: I was in prison for twenty-eight years.
Premeditated murder.
Just got out. Had me thirteen lawyers. Missed the electric chair twice. .. Been out three months. Are you heavy?
I'm forty-six. Do you like to go up or down?
High? Do you ever get high? A walk on the wild side. Ever do dust? All I need is fifteen minutes a night.
Sleep. That's all I need. Don't want to waste no time sleeping. You married?
My mother. died in '72. They told me after. They said they couldn't find me before, so they told us after.
They said go see the chaplain.
answer: I'm sorry but I have to go.

question: Well, for heaven's sake. You're just about everywhere, aren't you? I think I should tell you I know why you're here. The answer is no ... we don't get involved in politics.
answer: Well, that's not entirely true, Barnett. At least not according to Haven.

question: Haven? Hell,' we've been playing poker together since we were fourteen.
answer: I guess that's why he thought you right want to help out.

question: He knows better.
answer: Well, it's probably because it would help him.

question: How is that?
answer: Everybody likes to be as good as their word.

question: Whose word?
His word? Are you telling me Haven promised you something?
answer: That's pretty close. He's going to be on the bill. Why not put Barbara Jean on with him?

question: Barnett..
answer: Get her feet up. Okay, honey.

question: Oh, Barnett, I'm so sorry.
answer: Honey, it's okay... How do you feel now?

question: All those people...
answer: Don't worry, I'll take care or it

question: You're so good.
answer: She's fine now, folks. Just too soon after the hospital, I guess. She won't be able to continue and she's in the bus crying her eyes out, because she doesn't want to disappoint the people who love her the most.

question: We could invite them to the park.
They can come to the concert in the park.
answer: I said 'no!' We're very Sorry... Please... If you'll listen. You can see her tomorrow at Percy Warner Park... Triplette, I want to talk to you. I got trapped and you know it, so let's have some rules.

question: Absolutely. Listen, Barnett, I understand your position.
answer: No, you don't, so don't say you do. Bunch of damn liars. What do you get out or this?

question: Nothing; Barnett. It's my job.
answer: Your job, huh. She will not appear on the stage or support that Walker guy and you can't have any of his signs up while she sings. She'll be on first and out of the park before he shows up. There will be no pictures, no questions, no answers or tying her name up with his now or in the future to come. Any money she makes will go to the President of the United States. We'll see you tomorrow. I'll send her three songs over this afternoon. She'll be done about ten minutes after she starts and Walker better not show up till she's through. Now, get out of here. What? I'm very busy right now. Get me Haven. I don't know where you got this, but something tells me you stole it and I hate thieves. Aren't you an engineer...? I know you -- Don't you work at one of those cut a record places...? Twenty-five bucks a shot, isn't it? Usually their last twenty-five...

question: Hello, everybody. My name is Albuquerque. I'm going to sing a wonderful tune. Oh, I'm not through.
Hi! Star.
answer: Winifred, the kids want you home and so do I.

question: I won first prize.
You're really terrific, you know what I mean --LINNEA rolls over and faces him.
Wrong.
answer: I have to go. He sighs.

question: I know. Stay.
Car pool? When did you think it would happen?
I knew when I first met you.
How old are you?
Thirty?
I'm twenty-eight
Older than thirty? Terrific! Who was that black guy? A friend of yours?
Come on, you ever been attracted to a black guy? Just a minute. I'll talk to you tomorrow.
